Let $R$ be a ring and $\mathfrak{a}$ an ideal in $R$. The factor ring, or residue class ring, $R / \mathfrak{a}$, is defined initially as an abelian group by viewing $\mathfrak{a}$ as a (normal) subgroup of the additive group of $R$. The elements of $R / \mathfrak{a}$ are all residue classes of type $x+\mathfrak{a}$ for $x \in R$, where addition is given by $(x+\mathfrak{a})+(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x+y)+\mathfrak{a}$ and multiplication by $(x+\mathfrak{a}) \cdot(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x \cdot y)+\mathfrak{a}$. The ring properties of $R$ carry over to $R / \mathfrak{a}$.
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Does the concept of a/an Factor Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Center to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Center of a group involves the set of all elements in a group that commute with every other element in the group. This concept is purely group-theoretic and does not inherently involve any ring-theoretic properties or structures such as ideals or factor rings.

On the other hand, the concept of a Factor Ring involves a ring and an ideal within that ring, focusing on the construction of a new ring by considering equivalence classes of the ring elements modulo the ideal. This concept is specific to ring theory and does not directly relate to the group-theoretic concept of a center.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of the Center of a group do not require the concept of a Factor Ring. The Center can be fully understood and defined within the context of group theory alone, without any reference to ring theory or the concept of factor rings.
